facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1107 of 1963 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1107 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal arose from judgment and order dated September 8, 1959 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Civil Regular Appeal No. 17-D of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 8, 1959 of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi, in Civil Regular Appeal No. 17-D of 1954.

facts.text: Notification issued on March 2, 1937 under s. 7 of the Delhi Laws Act, 13 of 1912 extended United Provinces Town Improvement Act, 8 of 1919 to Delhi territory with modifications.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification issued on March 2, 1937 under s. 7 of the Delhi Laws Act, 13 of 1912, the Government of India extended, subject to certain modifications, the United Provinces

facts.text: Improvement Trust was set up under the Act for Delhi territory.

anchor.surface_text: Town Improvement Act, 8 of 1919, to the territory of Delhi, and thereafter set up an Improvement Trust under the Act for that territory.

facts.text: Trust prepared industrial development scheme to relieve congestion by inducing population flow from crowded parts of Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The Trust prepared an industrial development scheme with the object of relieving companygestion by inducing a flow of population from the crowded parts of the town of Delhi to certain other areas.

facts.text: Scheme sanctioned under s. 42 of the Act by Government of India and promulgated.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme was sanctioned under s. 42 of the Act by the government of India, and was duly promulgated.

facts.text: Trust resolved in June 1942 to make supplementary scheme as original land was inadequate.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Trust resolved in June 1942 to make a supplementary scheme as the land companyered by the original scheme was inadequate.

facts.text: Trust agreed to provide 268 acres to Delhi Cloth General Mills Co. Ltd. (Company) under resolution dated January 9, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: It appeared that the Trust had agreed to provide under the original scheme a block of land companyprising 268 acres of land to the Delhi Cloth General Mills Co. Ltd.-hereinafter called the Company -on certain

facts.text: Trust offered only 174.84 acres to Company under original scheme layout.

anchor.surface_text: terms and companyditions embodied in a resolution dated January 9, 1942, but the Trust was able to offer to the Company under the lay-out of the original scheme only 174.84 acres.

facts.text: Notice under s. 36 published on July 18, 1942 for supplementary scheme inviting objections within one month.

anchor.surface_text: On July,18, 1942 numberice under S. 36 of the Act was published in respect of the supplementary scheme for development of the industrial area, specifying the boundaries of the land

facts.text: No objections raised to supplementary scheme.

anchor.surface_text: in which the scheme was to be worked and inviting objections to the scheme, within one month from the date of publication. No objections were, it appears raised

facts.text: Supplementary scheme approved by resolution dated July 31, 1944 and notified under s. 42 on June 28, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: to the proposed supplementary scheme, and it was finally approved by resolution dated July 31, 1944, and was numberified under S. 42 of the Act on June 28, 1946.

facts.text: Land acquisition proceedings commenced under s. 58 and awards made for compensation.

anchor.surface_text: Land acquisition proceedings were then companymenced under s. 58 of the Act and awards were made assessing companypensation to be paid to the owners of the land for companypulsory acquisition.

facts.text: 13 bighas of land belonging to appellants included in notified scheme and acquired.

anchor.surface_text: In the scheme so numberified was included an area of 13 bighas of land belonging to the appellants and that land was acquired.

facts.text: Appellants sued Delhi Improvement Trust on May 3, 1949 for declaration that awards were wrong and illegal, no acquisition, and restrain possession.

anchor.surface_text: On May 3, 1949 the appellants sued the Delhi Improvement Trust for a declaration that the awards were wrong and illegal and did number result in acquisition of the suit property

facts.text: Appellants contended notification extending Act was invalid, Trust not lawfully constituted, schemes invalid, no power to acquire, procedural defects.

anchor.surface_text: and for an order restraining the Trust from taking possession of their lands under the awards and from interfering in any way with their enjoyment of the lands. The appellants

facts.text: Appellants contended scheme framed for benefit of Company.

anchor.surface_text: in support of their claim companytended that the numberification extending the United Provinces twon Improvement Act, 8 of 1919, was invalid, that the Improvement Trust was number lawfully

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Delhi held Act properly extended, scheme valid, power to acquire, but no evidence suit area necessary for scheme, decreed for appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge, Delhi, held that the Act was properly extended to the Delhi territory. that the scheme was valid and the Trust had power to acquire the land, but

facts.text: Senior Subordinate Judge affirmed decree of Trial Court.

anchor.surface_text: in the view of the Subordinate Judge there was numberhing on the record to show that the area in suit was necessary for or was affected by the execution of this scheme,

facts.text: Falshaw J. in Punjab High Court reversed decree, held original scheme valid, supplementary legitimate extension.

anchor.surface_text: In second appeal to the High Court of Punjab, Falshaw, J., reversed the decree passed by the First Appellate Court. In the view of the learned Judge, since the original

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court confirmed Falshaw J.'s decree.

anchor.surface_text: The decree passed by Falshaw, J., was companyfirmed by a Division Bench of the High Court.

facts.text: Appeal preferred to Supreme Court with certificate from High Court.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred.

facts.text: Trust resolved on June 30, 1942 to acquire additional 103.16 acres for sale to Company.

anchor.surface_text: On June 30, 1942 it was resolved by the Trust to acquire an additional area of 103.16 acres to be sold to the Company.

facts.text: Original scheme approved March 29, 1940 covering 479.81 acres.

anchor.surface_text: A reference is invited to Boards resolution No. 78 of the 29th March, 1940 relating to the Trusts Industrial Area Scheme. The scheme as approved by the Board

facts.text: Supreme Court held original scheme was town expansion scheme under s.24(h) and s.32, valid.

anchor.surface_text: The resolution of the Trust dated March 29, 1940, clearly indicates that the original scheme was intended to secure growth of an industrial area-

facts.text: Validity of original 1940 scheme not challenged before High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that neither before Falshaw, J., number before the High Court the validity of the original scheme of 1940 was challenged.

facts.text: Supplementary scheme for further progress of original scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The supple- mentary scheme, as the resolution dated June 30, 1942 clearly indicates, was framed for the further progress of the original scheme.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must therefore fail.

anchor.surface_text: The resolution of the Trust dated March 29, 1940, clearly indicates that the original scheme was intended to secure growth of an industrial area- and thereby to relieve congestion

arguments.claim: supplementary scheme framed for further progress of original scheme

arguments.claim: s.23(a) authorises acquisition of property necessary for or affected by scheme; applicable to town expansion

anchor.surface_text: Section 23(a) in terms authorises acquisition by purchase, exchange, or otherwise of any property necessary for or affected by the execution of the scheme.

arguments.claim: s.23(g) and s.65 allow sale of land in scheme

anchor.surface_text: Power to include provision for sale of land comprised in the scheme may competently be conferred under s.23(g) of the Act and may be exercised under s.65.

holdings.text: Such a scheme was primarily a town expansion scheme within the meaning of s. 24(h) read with s. 32.

anchor.surface_text: Such a scheme was primarily a town expansion scheme within the meaning of s. 24(h) read with s. 32. In framing such a scheme the provisions of a development scheme were incidentally incorporated, and that the Trust, by express enactment in s. 24 was competent to do.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Original scheme resolution shows intent for industrial growth to relieve congestion, fitting town expansion under ss.24(h),32; combines development features permissibly.

holdings.text: The supplementary scheme, as the resolution dated June 30, 1942 clearly indicates, was framed for the further progress of the original scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The supplementary scheme, as the resolution dated June 30, 1942 clearly indicates, was framed for the further progress of the original scheme. The scheme was one for town expansion, and acquisition of land for town expansion, i.e. providing for industrial development and making provision for the residence of employees in the industries and of others, would clearly fall within the terms of S. 24(h) read with S. 32.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Resolution links supplementary to original's progress; acquisition for town expansion/industrial development within Act purposes.

holdings.text: The original and the supplementary schemes must be regarded as one composite scheme conceived in the interests of industrial development and relief of congestion by inducing a flow of population from the congested areas.

anchor.surface_text: The original and the supplementary schemes must be regarded as one composite scheme conceived in the interests of industrial development and relief of congestion by inducing a flow of population from the congested areas. The object of the supplementary scheme was to effectuate the purpose of the original scheme and failure to frame that scheme may seriously have affected the utility of the original scheme.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Schemes composite for public benefit (congestion relief, industrial dev.); not private device despite later sale to company.

holdings.text: The argument that in a town expansion scheme under s. 32 read with s. 24(h) of the Act, there is no power to acquire land compulsorily is futile.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that in a town expansion scheme under s. 32 read with s. 24(h) of the Act, there is no power to acquire land compulsorily is futile. Section 23(a) in terms authorises acquisition by purchase, exchange, or otherwise of any property necessary for or affected by the execution of the scheme.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.23(a) applies to all schemes incl. town expansion; s.32 implies via compensation liability; ss.55-56 expressly authorize.

holdings.text: Nor is there any substance in the contention that the provisions of Part VII of the Land Acquisition Act had to be resorted to by the Trust for acquiring land which was to be allotted to a Company after development.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is there any substance in the contention that the provisions of Part VII of the Land Acquisition Act had to be resorted to by the Trust for acquiring land which was to be allotted to a Company after development. If the land is to be notified for acquisition under the Land Acquisition Act for a Company, the requirements of Part VII of the Land Acquisition Act must undoubtedly be complied with,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acquisition for Trust scheme execution, not 'for Company'; Part VII only for direct company acquisitions; later disposal under s.65 valid.

holdings.text: Power to include provision for sale of land comprised in the scheme may competently be conferred under s.23(g) of the Act and may be exercised under s.65.

anchor.surface_text: Power to include provision for sale of land comprised in the scheme may competently be conferred under s.23(g) of the Act and may be exercised under s.65. Mere inclusion of a power of sale of land acquired under a scheme does not therefore vitiate a scheme.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ss.23(g),65 expressly permit sale/disposal of scheme land post-acquisition.

holdings.text: Publication of a notification under sub-section (1) in respect of any scheme shall be conclusive evidence that the scheme has been duly framed and sanctioned.

anchor.surface_text: Section 42 provides Whenever the State Government sanctions an improvement scheme it shall announce the fact by notification, and except in the case of a deferred street scheme, development scheme, or town expansion scheme, the Trust shall forthwith proceed to execute the same. The publication of a notification under sub-section (1) in respect of any scheme shall be conclusive evidence that the scheme has been duly framed and sanctioned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory provision applied; no challenge succeeds against sanctioned/promulgated schemes.

anchor.surface_text: Such a scheme was primarily a town expansion scheme within the meaning of s. 24(h) read with s. 32. In framing such a scheme the provisions of a development scheme were incidentally incorporated, and that the Trust, by express enactment in s. 24 was competent to do.
The appeal must therefore fail.

edges.explanation: Holding that supplementary scheme framed for progress of original scheme addresses purpose of acquisition under supplementary scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The supplementary scheme, as the resolution dated June 30, 1942 clearly indicates, was framed for the further progress of the original scheme. The scheme was one for town expansion, and acquisition of land for town expansion, i.e. providing for industrial development and making provision for the residence of employees in the industries and of others, would clearly fall within the terms of S. 24(h) read with S. 32.
The appeal must therefore fail.

anchor.surface_text: The original and the supplementary schemes must be regarded as one composite scheme conceived in the interests of industrial development and relief of congestion by inducing a flow of population from the congested areas. The object of the supplementary scheme was to effectuate the purpose of the original scheme and failure to frame that scheme may seriously have affected the utility of the original scheme.
The appeal must therefore fail.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that in a town expansion scheme under s. 32 read with s. 24(h) of the Act, there is no power to acquire land compulsorily is futile. Section 23(a) in terms authorises acquisition by purchase, exchange, or otherwise of any property necessary for or affected by the execution of the scheme.
The appeal must therefore fail.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is there any substance in the contention that the provisions of Part VII of the Land Acquisition Act had to be resorted to by the Trust for acquiring land which was to be allotted to a Company after development. If the land is to be notified for acquisition under the Land Acquisition Act for a Company, the requirements of Part VII of the Land Acquisition Act must undoubtedly be complied with,
The appeal must therefore fail.
The appeal must therefore fail.
